title: National Bank's Earnings Fall Short on Capital-Markets Miss
description: National Bank of Canada’s earnings came up just short of estimates as its capital-markets business failed to match analysts’ forecasts for a unit that’s benefited f…
content:
(Bloomberg) — National Bank of Canada’s earnings came up just short of estimates as its capital-markets business failed to match analysts’ forecasts for a unit that’s benefited from market volatility around this year’s tariff chaos. The company’s shares slipped.

The Montreal-based lender earned C$2.68 a share on an adjusted basis in its fiscal third quarter, according to a statement Wednesday, missing the C$2.70 average estimate of analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Net income at the firm’s financial-markets unit totaled C$334 million ($241 million) for the three months through July, less than the C$365 million average forecast of four analysts in a Bloomberg survey.

That comes after National Bank posted record results in its capital-markets division in the second quarter on supercharged trading revenue thanks to market swings in the wake of US President Donald Trump’s tariff announcements in early April.

Still, the company is “very happy with our results,” Chief Executive Officer Laurent Ferreira said, noting that profit was up from a year earlier in the capital-markets business. April had been a “perfect storm” of high volatility and extremely elevated trading activity, which works in the bank’s favor from a structural perspective, he said, but that subsided in the third quarter.

“We’ve always communicated this to investors: when there are times of heightened volatility, we should do better,” Ferreira said in an interview. “And when there’s less volume, our trading activity is lower.”

“So far, it’s been a really good journey,” Ferreira said, adding that the company began bringing employees on board in the spring and did its first integration of retail and commercial clients two weeks ago, including converting one of the CWB branches to the National Bank banner. He expects to finish switching over customers to the National Bank platform by the end of the year.
summary: National Bank of Canada's Q3 earnings fell short of estimates, largely due to its capital-markets business, which has benefited from market volatility during this year's tariff chaos. The company earned C$2.68 per share on an adjusted basis, which fell short against the average of analysts in a Bloomberg survey. Net income at the financial-markets unit totaled C$334 million ($241 million) for the three months through July, less than the C$365 million average forecast of four analysts. Despite this, National Bank's CEO, Laurent Ferreira, remains "very happy" with the results.
shortSummary: National Bank of Canada's earnings fell short of forecasts despite strong capital-markets performance, with shares falling despite record trading revenue from the recent market volatility.

argos_summary: National Bank of Canada reported fiscal third‑quarter earnings slightly below analyst expectations, with its capital‑markets unit posting C$334 million in net income versus a C$365 million forecast. CEO Laurent Ferreira said the bank remains pleased, noting year‑over‑year profit gains but lower trading activity after the high‑volatility period that boosted Q2 results. The bank is also integrating retail and commercial clients, converting a CWB branch to its brand, and aims to complete the switch to its platform by year‑end.
